Information Page

CGI Using AI

Computer-generated imagery (CGI) is a specific technology or application of computer graphics for creating or improving images in art, printed media, simulators, videos and video games. Modern CGI is increasingly powered by AI, which streamlines and enhances the entire production pipeline—from generating realistic 3D models and animations to automating lighting, rendering, and facial expressions. AI tools can now create lifelike environments and characters with minimal human input, optimize resource usage for sustainability, and even manage workflows autonomously through agentic systems. This integration not only speeds up production but also reduces costs and environmental impact, making CGI more efficient and scalable than ever before.

How Using AI Is Positive

AI-powered CGI positively impacts multiple facets of life: it enhances society by making education and healthcare more engaging and accessible through immersive simulations; it boosts the economy by reducing production costs and accelerating creative workflows in industries like film, gaming, and advertising; it enriches culture by digitally preserving and revitalizing historical artifacts and traditions; and it supports the environment by optimizing rendering processes to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions.

How Using AI Is Negative

AI-powered CGI also brings several challenges across different domains. Socially, it can contribute to misinformation by generating hyper-realistic fake content that’s hard to distinguish from reality. Economically, it may displace jobs in traditional animation and visual effects roles due to automation. Culturally, over-reliance on AI-generated content risks homogenizing creative expression and diminishing human artistic diversity. Environmentally, despite some efficiencies, large-scale AI rendering still consumes significant energy, contributing to digital carbon footprints.
